nodes.bodyText:
The overridable method should get TableMetadata.
We should assume the table properties are translated into single contigyous string
remove
copyright
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,9 @@
+package io.prestosql.plugin.sqlserver;

nodes.bodyText: How about verifying if all partitions have this enabled. If so you can set it to true, if all have disabled then false, otherwise you can return null. Do you think this is expensive to query sys.partitions?
SQL Server connector is not aware of underlying partitioning. Why do we care in this case?
I am thinking from Presto perspective, there is a table property that can be set via CREATE TABLE but SHOW CREATE TABLE is not returning it. Looks strange.

i agree with this.
btw
what will happen if a new partition is added on sql server side?
will it implicitly copy compression attribute from some other partiiton?
otherwise, the "table property" can appear "unset"...
I think it will refer to the compression type specified when creating a table

what will happen if a new partition is added on sql server side?

We should not care as long querying sys.partitions is a source of truth.

I think it will refer to the compression type specified when creating a table

where is it stored on sql server side?
Can you add an explicit test for SHOW CREATE TABLE output?
testWithDataCompression -> testCreateWithDataCompression
test_create_ -> test_create_with_compression
drop the table too

add
checkArgument(tableMetadata.getProperties().isEmpty(), "Unsupported table properties: %s", tableMetadata.getProperties());

This is correct because currently SQL Server does not seem to support enabling table compression by default for a schema or database. However, they can add in the future.
Therefore today NONE is a good default, but can become a wrong choice without a code change on our part.
Let's replace NONE with UNSET (or DEFAULT). Then do not add WITH (DATA_COMPRESSION clause when compression is the UNSET.
cc @kokosing

Correct me if I am wrong, NONE means no compression.

Let's replace NONE with UNSET (or DEFAULT). Then do not add WITH (DATA_COMPRESSION clause when compression is the UNSET.

Let's implement UNSET by not setting property value, so let's make it nullable and when it is null we should just use sql server system default behaviour.
But when we run SHOW CREATE TABLE for any table from SQLServer we won't be able to capture the UNSET/DEFAULT rather we get only NONE. How can we handle in that situation ?

This is not safe. Should SQL Server add new compression mode (say, "BLOCK"), we don't want to fail the method here. I'd rather return no property.
also, is there a test ensuring SHOW CREATE TABLE doesn't return unnecessary data_compression property for all tables now?

is there a test ensuring SHOW CREATE TABLE doesn't return unnecessary data_compression property for all tables now

That property will now be added. I think we should skip it when it is value is unknown (null), when it differs among paritions.

what if we get two rows? validate & fail in such a case, this means our query is wrong
verify(!resultSet.next(), "Unexpected second result row");

As you explained to me offline, the SQL Server treats table with single partition as an unpartitioned table.
Is there a guarantee that the only partition will have partition_number=1?
Also, in case of a partitioned table, we should not return compression info from the first partition.

From their documentation it looks like they set partition_number as 1 for non-partitioned tables.
Ref : https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/system-catalog-views/sys-partitions-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15
This answers the first question.
From their docs it looks like 1 is used only for non-partitioned tables
Wonder why we need to specify the default twice -- above and here.
nit: i'd put this below the test method, but up to you
you might want to replace multiple subsequent white characters in to a single space, then value of createQuery would be easier to maintain.
jdbi3?
But for using JDBI we might need inject a ConnectionProvider but for fetching a connection we need to JdbcIdentity
i didn't quite get it. Anyway, you can attach jdbi to an existing connector.
this is not needed. It is only needed you would place ; at the end.

nodes.bodyText: I would love to see a test where data_compression = null. Where table is created remotely (outside of Presto) and its partitions have different compressions. Is that doable?

nodes.bodyText: what about other partitions? What they have different data_compression_desc? I would do SELECT DISTINCT data_compression_desc and in case there is 0 or more than 1 row I would return Optional.empty()
does getIfPresent supports - replacement with _ or does it compare it case insensitively?  No change request.
Shouldn't you return Optional here?
We passed a default value to enumProperty so it should be non-null I guess

So I guess default should be null (unknown, don't care (default when you create a table)).
We should return NONE if we known that all table partitions are not compressed.

Could you please consider different name for this method?

usually get is a lightweight one.
currently it repeats the class name.

Maybe take or takeFor?
I like current name. I don't like suffixes in method like For, it adds no value but makes method longer. It is obvious that method will return a value for given parameters.
Actually I think DataCompressionDao class is not needed, all you need is getDataCompression method.

I'm fine with prefix get as long as it's clearly stated that it's dao, and it is.
With shorter name for method (maybe just get(JdbcTableHandle table)) I like this class. If the name left as is static method is enough.

Could you please make this query more vertical than horizontal or share your thoughts why is it so onliner?
Maybe FROM and INNER JOIN from new line?
separate commit?
This test was to ensure that it doesn't show data_compression for partitioned tables. Have updated the method name
What if query returns more than one record, is it going to throw?
Yes !! If it return 0 value it returns Optional#empty if more than 1 row it throws an exception
